ratings.comment: A lot better than most of the reviews say, he was thorough in explaining the content, and following his example problems is a great way to learn. He clearly cared about the content, and explained the real world uses for the math you're learning better than any other professor I've had.

This course has 4 exams that are worth enough to fail you but not enough to save your grade. You are pretty much required to do the homework to pass the course. Besides that you also have to read the textbook. He knows the material well but has no idea how to teach. Get ready to learn from the TAs(if you are lucky) and the textbook.

Weekly tests weren't too bad content-wise, but they mattered a lot for grades. The lectures were easy to follow and understand, but could get dull at times. Prof Mermelstein was a great professor for me, and the language barriers mentioned by earlier reviews is non-existent (at least anymore).

Honestly enjoyed his online lectures. They were Asynchronous, but he made it seem just like any other normal math class. Very easy to learn the material. 10/10 recommend writing down any homework problems cause it should be very similar to what is on exams. Lot of work but worth it.

Hes definitely an intelligent guy.  It would be great to talk to him if I understood what hes saying and enjoyed mathematics. Unfortunately he doesnt explain things very well to us mortals in an introductory calculus class. He might be better at teaching high level math courses, but if youre taking a gen ed class Id avoid this professor.

I had Prof. Mermelstein for Math 234 and it was much better than the reviews on here say. His lectures were asynchronous (use 2x speed) and he seemed reasonable overall. There were weekly open note mini tests, so it's important that you have good notes. Online testing means small mistakes can tank your grade, even if your work is good.
He is a pretty nice professor. I had his asynchronous class. Sometimes he does interesting tricks in his recorded videos. Well if you watch every video and take notes, you will do fine in his class:)

Actually, for A1 asynchronous sessions, Prof. Mermelstein is reasonably fine. His videos are short and sweet and the workload is pretty light. He allows students to use PHYSICAL NOTES during exams including the FINAL. Just take some notes and follow his directions, you will be fine!

A lot of people kind of dog him for doing badly but I went to every lecture. He always encouraged questions. In high school, I only got up to pre-calculus and almost failed it. I hadn't taken calculus since junior year of high school upon entering this class and if you just put work in you'll do fine. It's not easy but he doesn't do a bad job.
He is awful... Does not explain any material. Yelled at kids in class for asking a question in class.

Took Math341 with Omer a year ago. Class was very hard particularly when you try to take too many notes. But remember not to take notes since all are in textbook. You will learn a lot and get inapiration in Mathematical thinking if you just listen. Omer is really patient if you ask questions . Grading is not too bad as your progress is considered.

One of the worst professors I have ever had. Lectures are not only incomprehensible and incredibly boring, the prof barely covers any actual material that is covered on the test. He relies extremely heavily on his TAs to pick up the work he did not do in lecture. I do not recommend taking this class.

Professor Mermelstein gave very wishy-washy grading requirements. He didn't explain the curve until the last day. Sometimes there was a bit of a language barrier, and he was condescending at times. On exams, the questions were unnecessarily difficult, but the class was curved, so I guess we had that going for us,

If you did not take calc in high school then you are going to struggle. I took calc in high school and I can tell you he did an EXTREMELY poor job of explaining everything. He spent one 50 minute lecture on derivatives which should take at least two. If you have no experience then you better get ready to spend HOURS teaching yourself.

A lot of reviews on here haven't been fair at all. If you don't go to lecture and don't read the textbook you probably won't do well. But if you listen to his lectures and take the initiative to learn a bit outside of class you will be fine. Also people complaining about the grading weren't listening because he made the curve pretty clear.

I think the main problem isn't Omer himself, but the class structure of Math 211. If you are in the b-school or looking to apply to the b-school I recommend taking Math 221 because it is way closer to an actual calc 1 class. This class covers mainly topics from Calc 1 but had Calc 2 and 3 topics in it, making the class very difficult at times.

Worst professor I've ever had. Seems like he is teaching himself and moves on once he understands it after reteaching the concepts to himself, and we happen to be listening in the background. An embarrassment of a "professor"/"teacher" causing misery to students.

Omer is certainly an intelligent professor, but should not be teaching 211. Do not take his Math211 as your Calc 1 course (as it is described on guide) at UW. He is teaching Calc 3 content and not thoroughly explaining concepts that deserve more than a quick 'explanation'. If you enroll in this, make sure you're confident teaching yourself.

Omer is definitely a smart person, but not great at explaining things. The class is definitely structured and taught under the assumption that you took Calc in high school, which I unfortunately did not. But if you do the readings from the textbook and the homework consistently, the class itself is not actually as hard as it seems!

Omer wants you to succeed, however the pace is very fast and many concepts are brushed over. It feels like they give you the basic concept to practice and understand, but the tests always are much harder.

He is definitely not the best, but not as bad as people are saying on here . If you took calc in high school, you're fine. He can be entertaining sometimes, but the grading is pretty confusing + he isn't the greatest explainer. My TA was better at explaining. Do the assigned readings, book problems, and go to discussion. Overall, didn't mind him.
He is a decent professor if you've already taken Calculus. Definitely makes you work to get an A.
If youre in the b school and did well on the placement test, dont take 211 because its the easiest class. Just take a harder math because this specific class structure and pacing sucks.

Worst teacher I have ever had. I took Calculus in high school and thought it was simple. Omer on the other hand, takes simple concepts and turns them into something impossible. I give him credit because you can tell he is a very smart person but just sucks at teaching. Get ready to teach yourself and watch every youtube video available.
Not as bad as other reviews say. Course grading is a little unorganized but if you go to class and listen you will be fine!

Easily the worst teacher I have ever had. I took calculus last year and some how understand it less now. He overcomplicates everything and gives unnecessarily difficult problems on the quizzes and midterms. His notes during lecture are messy, disorganized, and confusing. They are simply definitions from the book which do not add to my understanding

Worst teacher I've ever had. Impossible to learn from because he makes every concept needlessly hard. Refuses to tell students what the weekly quizzes will be on and we have no way to prepare. Honestly don't know if I'm going to pass.

Omer is not a great professor. He makes comments suggesting his students are dumb. He makes the TA grade everything much harder than it needs to be graded and overall they make what could be a very easy class way too hard for no reason. The TA's and Omer don't tell you directly what is on every quiz and the quizzes are unnecessarily hard.
Terrible. Makes the math way more difficult than it should be. Does a terrible job explaining and leaves you out to dry.

He makes simple math harder than it needs to be and the lectures are stright from the text book with little explanation. Doesn't seem to care about his students or questions students have. Both him and the TAs never say what is to be expected on weekly quizzes and are unhelpful.

It's not a hard class, but it's so unorganized. Prof & TAs refuse to answer questions like, what topics will be on the next quiz & what topics will be covered on the second midterm (not cumulative, a fair question). He doesn't really teach anything and when he does he teaches in the most obscure way. The TAs have attitudes so are hard to work with.

He is by far the worst professor I have ever had. He makes fun of students in lecture when they ask questions he deems are stupid. He writes so small and fast on the chalkboard that no one has any clue what he is writing. He rarely explains examples and when he does, no one can understand him because his work is usually unreadable
